text: Ridiculousness is an American comedy clip show that began airing on August 29, 2011. It is hosted by Rob Dyrdek and co-hosted by Sterling "Steelo" Brim and Chanel West Coast. Some episodes feature a celebrity special guest. Ridiculousness shows various viral videos from the Internet, usually involving failed do-it-yourself attempts at stunts, to which Rob and his panelists add mock commentary. Although the format bears some similarity to viewer- submission driven shows such as America's Funniest Home Videos, Ridiculousness producers, as well as the show's network, MTV, do not accept viewer submissions and air a disclaimer before and after each episode warning that, because of the dangerous nature of the stunts being shown, any attempts to submit a video to the show will not be considered. ==Series overview== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" |Season ! rowspan="2" |Episodes ! colspan="2" |Originally aired |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #8A4500; color: #FFFFFF;" width=20% | Original air date ! scope="col" style="background-color: #8A4500; color: #FFFFFF;" width=14% | U.S. viewers (million) |- |} Ending Segment: "Chanel's Best Guess" - At the end of each episode, Rob would display two words on the screen (in the Eddie Barbanell episode, three), and have Chanel guess what type of video would play. ===Season 4 (2014)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #00AE00; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in series ! scope="col" style="background-color: #00AE00; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in season ! scope="col" style="background-color: #00AE00; color: #FFFFFF;"| Guest ! scope="col" style="background-color: #00AE00; color: #FFFFFF;" width=20% | Original air date ! scope="col" style="background-color: #00AE00; color: #FFFFFF;" width=14% | U.S. viewers (million) |- |} Ending Segment: "B.Y.O.C." (Bring Your Own Clip) - At the end of each episode in Season 4, Rob would allow the guest to bring a clip of their choice. If there was no guest, then either Rob, Sterling, or Chanel would provide the clip (in the Jackson Nicoll episode, Rob brought the clip instead of Jackson). ===Season 5 (2014)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #D4ED91; color: #000000;" width=7% | No. in series ! scope="col" style="background-color: #D4ED91; color: #000000;" width=7% | No. in season ! scope="col" style="background-color: #D4ED91; color: #000000;"| Guest ! scope="col" style="background-color: #D4ED91; color: #000000;" width=20% | Original air date ! scope="col" style="background-color: #D4ED91; color: #000000;" width=14% | U.S. viewers (million) |- |} Ending Segment: "Hashtag It" - At the end of each episode in the first half of Season 5, Rob would show a clip and Rob, Sterling, Chanel, and the guest would try to apply a funny hashtag to it. In the second half of Season 5 (starting with the Kylie and Kendall Jenner episode), the hashtag was revealed first, and the group would try to guess what kind of video would play. ===Season 6 (2015)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #030695; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in series ! scope="col" style="background-color: #030695; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in season ! scope="col" style="background-color: #030695; color: #FFFFFF;"| Guest ! scope="col" style="background-color: #030695; color: #FFFFFF;" width=20% | Original air date ! scope="col" style="background-color: #030695; color: #FFFFFF;" width=14% | U.S. viewers (million) |- |} Ending Segment: "Clip Roulette" - At the end of each episode, Rob would display stills of three different clips and the guest (or Chanel or Sterling) would choose one to play. The Mr. Rochelle episode and the Chanel and Sterling XVI episodes were originally taped for Season 5, so those two episodes features the "Hashtag It" closing segment. The episode with Brooks Wheelan did not include an ending segment. ===Season 7 (2015–16)=== Note: The first two episodes of this season were shot in New York at 1515 Broadway as opposed to Los Angeles. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FFFF33; color: black;" width=7% | No. in series ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FFFF33; color: black;" width=7% | No. in season ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FFFF33; color: black;"| Guest ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FFFF33; color: black;" width=20% | Original air date ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FFFF33; color: black;" width=14% | U.S. viewers (million) |- |} Ending Segment: Unlike previous seasons, the ending segment varied between each episode in Season 7. The most common segments are "Flash Forward", where Rob would play two clips in the style of "before and after", and "Not What It Looks/Sounds Like", where Rob would play a questionable sound or video clip, only to have it become something totally unexpected. Later episodes in the season omitted the ending segment. ===Season 8 (2016)=== Note: The oversized laptop is replaced with a new set. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FF22FF; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in series ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FF22FF; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in season ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FF22FF; color: #FFFFFF;"| Guest ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FF22FF; color: #FFFFFF;" width=20% | Original air date ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FF22FF; color: #FFFFFF;" width=14% | U.S. viewers (million) |} Ending Segment: Like season 7, this varies between 2 segments, "Clip Hybrid" - where Rob would take two or more clips and mash them up together; and "Slo-Mo Ender" - where a slow-motion clip is played. ===Season 9 (2017)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FB4F14; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in series ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FB4F14; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in season ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FB4F14; color: #FFFFFF;"| Guest ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FB4F14; color: #FFFFFF;" width=20% | Original air date ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FB4F14; color: #FFFFFF;" width=14% | U.S. viewers (million) |} Ending Segment: "_____ Or _____?" - At the end of each episode in Season 9, Rob would ask a question in the form of "this or that", i.e. "Flash or Splash", and play a clip depending on their response. Although sometimes, the ending clip has both elements. ===Season 10 (2017–18)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FA9244; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in series ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FA9244; color: #FFFFFF;" width=7% | No. in season ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FA9244; color: #FFFFFF;"| Guest ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FA9244; color: #FFFFFF;" width=20% | Original air date ! scope="col" style="background-color: #FA9244; color: #FFFFFF;" width=14% | U.S. viewers (million) |} End segment: this season contained multiple end segments. The "____ or ____?" ending returns from Season 9, but also seen is "Crowd Control", where Rob shows the names of two clips and allows the audience to choose which clip they would like to see by show of applause; and "Back That Clip Up", where Rob plays a clip backwards. ===Season 11 (2018)=== Note: The season premiered on August 5, 2018 and ended on October 12, 2018. This season has an all-new logo and the background of the set was changing color from red to blue. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #CAD120; color: black;" width=7% | No. in series !
